qas.question: Who showed that extinct South American fossils were related to living species?
What did John Gould announce in 1837?

answers.text: Darwin's rhea was a separate species from the previously described rhea

qas.question: How many species of mockingbirds were found to be present on the Galapagos Islands?
What type of scientist was John Gould?
Which animal did Darwin see at a zoo that made him further consider evolution?

context: <a0_0>Richard Owen<a0_0/> showed that fossils of extinct species Darwin found in South America were allied to living species on the same continent. In March 1837, <a3_0>ornithologist<a3_0/> John Gould announced that <a1_0>Darwin's rhea was a separate species from the previously described rhea<a1_0/> (though their territories overlapped), that mockingbirds collected on the Galápagos Islands represented <a2_0>three separate species<a2_0/> each unique to a particular island, and that several distinct birds from those islands were all classified as finches. Darwin began speculating, in a series of notebooks, on the possibility that "one species does change into another" to explain these findings, and around July sketched a genealogical branching of a single evolutionary tree, discarding Lamarck's independent lineages progressing to higher forms. Unconventionally, Darwin asked questions of fancy pigeon and animal breeders as well as established scientists. At the zoo he had his first sight of <a4_0>an ape<a4_0/>, and was profoundly impressed by how human the orangutan seemed.
